comments.commentBody: Did you read the article? It was about how Apple treats its customers in China. The law in China states that the warranty period is 2 years. Idiosyncratic? Apple is an outstanding company; they are responsive to customer concerns. I know this from firsthand experience. My family and I have a number of Apple products. My child did have numerous problems/repairs with one computer, but Apple graciously swapped it out for a new one. I think, of course, that Apple has to be sensitive to the particular idiosyncrasies of a country like China in which its chosen to do business.

I don't agree with all the Apple-bashing in the comments though. Apple tries to do right by its customers.

In China, you get a jingoistic "expose" produced by state-run TV. I guess there can only be so much juice left in the budget after you're done funding the world's most elaborate censorship and corporate espionage programs...
The primary difference between the tainted Chinese products mentioned above and the American combat drones mentioned below: the drones are well-made and work properly.

Americans are employed building cars for sale in the US, not for export to China or anywhere else.  Apple is building abroad for current and future overseas customers.  Americans will buy only a shrinking share of Apple's products, not most, not even half, already less than half, with the American market continuing to become a smaller slice of the world's pie.

While I have no trouble with your atheist position, you actually err in quite a number of ways.

First, religious faith is not eroding; rather, what the Pew and other polls show is that, while it is true that more atheists are self-identifying as such, and believers are falling way from organized, mainstream religion, those believers are maintaining their faith in other ways; e.g., home and community churches.

Second, to suggest that in a world in which almost one-half of the populace believes in one of the three monotheistic religions (Judaism, Christianity, Islam) religious faith is "eroding" is truly odd.

Third, by implying that people of faith do not care about "global warming, over-population, loss of biodiversity, global food production, pollution, etc." is to paint believers with an absurdly broad brush, and even to suggest that their positions on these issues are monolithic. This is simply not the case.

Finally, the "rituals" that go along with a particular believers' faith have little or nothing to do with their positions on the issues of the day.

It would seem imprudent to alienate millions of actual or potential allies in the causes you care about by simply dismissing or denigrating believers in toto. We need all the voices and bodies we can get to fight for those causes.

Peace.

I am somewhat skeptical. The Nordic countries are benefiting from the North Sea oil boom; that has to skew any observations to blur the effects of austerity. Wealth from exploitation of natural resources requires active government intervention to convert the short term boom into long term prosperity.
As far as the US bleeding money to the rest of the world: just like water, money tends to flow downhill. As the wealthiest nation in the world, the US can maintain its position only by significant wealth creation. In a modern economy, that can only be achieved through innovation; we cannot follow the Roman Empire's approach of conquest and tribute. Innovation requires significant government investments in basic research and education (because of the diffuse nature of benefits, only the government can profit through an increase in tax revenue), and through industrial R&D to take advantage of potential new technology. Austerity (and conservative policy more generally) hits these areas first, and the last 30 years have seen significant decline in effective government investments, especially considering that basic research has gotten more expensive (we have solved the "easier" problems; harder problems require increasingly capable and thus more expensive hardware).

@Susan Anderson

With your willingness to champion scientific rubbish as well as a lack of integrity the question becomes whether there is any crime against science or the truth that you're unwilling to champion and defend.

Susan, Ross McKitrick summarized the problem with Marcott very well. ( http://opinion.financialpost.com/2013/04/01/were-not-screwed/). Take a look, you don't need a science degree (or your Daddy) to understand the issues clearly. Intelligence can be your friend, if you have an open mind.

McIntyre can hardly "credibly" criticize anyone's work since he does not manage to publish his pot shots in the peer-reviewed literature but instead relies on the unsophisticated to lap up his nonsense.

Tamino, on the other hand, does attempt to publish his work for all to see and criticize in the appropriate forum, and he does get published.

I'm pretty sure whose work I would rely on more.

McIntyre should retract his untruthful charge of plagiarism.

Tamino clarifies the issues with verve and panache, and a mite of understandable irritation:

http://tamino.wordpress.com/2013/04/02/for-the-record/

It opens thusly:

"All I "learned" from McIntyre's "analysis" is that Marcott et al. had re-calibrated proxy ages, that McIntyre blamed the uptick on the re-dating process, and that he was happy to hint at the possibility of deliberate deception on the part of the authors. The references to McIntyre in my original version were to his insulting tone regarding this work, but I finally decided it was better to ignore that and comment on the science. It now seems that on the "dot earth" blog he chose to accuse me of having "shamelessly plagiarized" his ideas on why the exaggerated uptick occurs in the Marcott et al. temperature reconstruction. He's wrong.

"I didn't read all his posts about the paper, for two reasons: first, there are so many, and I find them so full of sneering and thinly veiled innuendo that they're sickening; second, there's really very little to be learned from him. In my opinion he's just not interested in understanding the science, he only wants to kill hockey sticks."

It only takes a few dozen people in a venue like this, especially with the complicity of the blog owner, who may only wish to appear "fair", to make up look like down. Where a large majority of the facts are on one side, 50:50 is a distortion.

Very sad, for us and for the leaders who seek to mislead.

And who says that we are all supposed to "celebrate the larger sense of spiritual belonging"? What the heck does that mean? I guess that's the sort of new-age, feel-good, no-obligation hooey that people are seeking when they say something idiotic like "I'm not reglious, but I am spiritual."

There is no question but that religion has been misused throughout history as a force for evil. But it also gives people a sense of meaning, belonging, and community. Religious groups help feed the hungry, comfort the grieving, and give lost people a home. Religion is a key component of culture, and provides a moral and ehtical framework in which to live your life and raise your family. it is about so much more than virgins and underwear.

But what do I know? Because, as you wrote: "no one with any sense would buy it for a minute." But I do, and I am better for it.

@bimber,
Imagine that religion was not taught to young children, but instead all the tenets of the major faiths were revealed in, say, a college seminar. Students would hear for the first time about life after death, miraculous burning bushes and virgin births, and invisible realms populated by supernatural beings who promise both impossible rewards and unimaginable punishments. At the end of the course students would be told that they would be assigned a religion based mostly on their country and community of birth. They would be obliged to take it seriously, and there would be social, familial, and employment problems if they openly expressed disbelief.

I doubt that there would be many converts. For religion to take hold it must be taught to young children, long before their abilities to reason and think critically are fully developed. This is why we wait to teach physics and evolutionary biology to students in college; but we feel justified in teaching the arcane mysteries of theology and metaphysics to 5-year-olds.

We can do good works without the encumbrance of religion. We can feel purpose and have a sense of morality that does not derive from brutal first-century tribal collectives. We can build our ethics on a foundation that does not periodically inflict evil on the world.

"They usually acquire the faith of their parents"

What abour converts?

And I don't mean converts to the faith of a prospective spouse; I mean converts who don't have a spouse in view or who are already married. This is the age if conversion and it's not all conversion to "no religion."

People aren't born believing in religion. They usually acquire the faith of their parents, not because of the overwhelmingly convincing nature of the religion, but because they were told to believe it by the people who happened to be nearby. It goes in easily, because children don't have the ability to think critically about what they're being told.

Religion, like language, goes in early, and imprints on the developing brain. It seems "right" the way that Italian seems right to a child born in Italy. Who can tell you that your language is wrong, or that your religion is wrong? They're not about right and wrong.

So when people find their mate later in life, how sad if they're kept apart because one believes in the virgin birth and the other believes in magic underwear. We're supposed to embrace all religious faiths these days. We are told to look past the dogmatic differences and celebrate the larger sense of spiritual belonging.

But that doesn't happen. We didn't learn about spiritual belonging when we were young. We learned about virgin births and magic underwear. This is the true currency of religion: absurd beliefs that must be taught to children, because no one with any sense would buy it for a minute. And yet these are the things that stand in the way of the love two people may have for one another.

What a waste.

Religion was said to bring tangible earthly rewards. When that seemed too ridiculous, they invented the afterlife. Then human morality was said to spring exclusively from one's religious identity. The summary of your comment is to suggest if children are not indoctrinated early, they could end up evaluating a philosophy objectively and strictly on its merits. This doesn't have anything to do with good dental hygiene, of which I am an apostle, so don't drag my faith into your argument, rabbi. I say if you don't take care of your teeth, they will fall out. That's more truth than any church or synagogue will offer you.

I hope for a lot more mediocrity, if you are the alternative.

The comment is somewhat understandable from your point of view. It is nevertheless wrong. It is unfortunate that you equate religion with "identity". A kid's identity should come from many sources, and a particular religion can be one of them. It should never, ever be the only one.
I also object to your use of the term "mediocre" when describing Jews or Christians that do not blindly follow the dogma of their faith. Many of us contribute equally, and often more, to the betterment of our communities and the world than those who are considered observant Christians or Jews.

At important times in our adult lives we return to expectations anchored in our psyche from our childhood. Those who come from religiously observant families will be drawn to these observances (communion, bar mitzvah, haj, christmas tree, seder...) again--especially when it comes to raising children. Those who were raised in families with a lukewarm or neutral or even hostile connection to religious observance will not feel this pull. In other words, it is not difficult for a mediocre Jew to be married to a mediocre Christian and vice versa if they share, say, political or cultural values.
But a plea: you don't give your children the choice of whether or not to brush their teeth. Don't give them the option to choose (or not) an identity. They need one--even if they later reject it. Don't make them choose between mother's or father's religion. They will likely opt for neither--rather than feel like they are betraying the one not chosen. This is not fair nor is it a good way to raise a child. Give children a positive identity and also a questioning mind so that they may think for themselves and eventually choose what to believe.

I had hoped to forget this, but you just had to write this story about autographed baseballs.  My father was in the Marine Corps in World War II.  He was wounded in the Pacific during one of the several island invasions.  He was flown back to Honolulu and hospitalized for the better part of a year.  His Naval corpsman was a young man by the name of Virgil "Fire" Trucks.  Of course my father got him to autograph a baseball which he shipped back to the states for me.  Just a 10-year old kid who loved to play baseball in the neighborhood lot, I took it out to show it off, and, of course to play a game of ball with my friends with it.  It was beat up some, of course, but salvageable.  Over the years, I somehow managed to lose it.  Thanks for reminding me how valuable it might have been now.  Virgil "Fire" Trucks just recently passed away.
